---
layout: post
title:      "The Seinfeld"
date:       2019-07-29 10:44:51 -0400
permalink:  the_seinfeld
---


Seinfeld is and always has been one of my all time favourite shows, so when I saw the complete ['Seinfeld Chronicles'](https://www.kaggle.com/thec03u5/seinfeld-chronicles) data set on Kaggle I was speechless, I had no speech.

![](https://media3.giphy.com/media/12UlfHpF05ielO/giphy.gif?cid=790b76115d3f0c2145656563772f12f0&rid=giphy.gif)

The idea of applying deep learning to Seinfeld seemed strange at first, starting out I was just happy to play around inside the data and discover interesting things like 'Larry David wrote the most episodes of Seinfeld with 58 credits' and 'George speaks more than Elaine in every season except Season 6' and 'Superman is mentioned 24 time in in 17 episodes' .  But it was that Larry David fact that come back to and stuck in my mind. His number of writing credits greatly dwarfs the next most prolific writer (a tie between Peter Mehlman and Larry Charles on 19 each).  Larry David's role is especially crucial early in the series where 'Seinfeld' is not yet popular and is still finding its feet as a show. Larry David wrote 4 of the 5 episodes of the first season and 8 of the 12 episodes in the second season. In the third season his over all number of episodes increases to 14  but by this time the series has a full 23 episode run. As a writer, Larry David effectively built the show into what it became and wrote who the characters were and who they would become.

![](data:image/png;base64,%0A)

## The Larry David Classifier

Larry David's contribution to Seinfeld is monumental. His amazing 58 episodes worth of writing credits is one third of the total episodes. His influence on the characters and style of the show is singular and immeasurable, or is it?  The Larry David Factor quickly became my chief interest in the dataset and I went down Larry David rabbit hole.
